title: Rationale for Multimodal Fusion
description: Discuss the limitations of relying solely on EEG for fatigue detection and the potential benefits of incorporating other physiological signals and behavioral measures. Highlight the potential benefits of incorporating other physiological signals (e.g., ECG, EOG, EMG) and behavioral measures (e.g., eye tracking, facial expressions, vehicle dynamics)

examples.description: Assesses mental fatigue using multiple biosignals (EEG, EOG, EDA, PPG), enhancing safety in automated driving.
examples.note: Added for illustrating the assessment of mental fatigue using a wide array of biosignals, demonstrating the value of multimodal data in enhancing safety.

examples.description: Utilizes multimodal biosignals, including EEG, ECG, respiration, and EDA, for classifying pilots' mental states.
examples.note: Added for its use of multimodal biosignals in classifying pilots' mental states, showcasing the application of multimodal data in safety-critical professions beyond driving.

examples.description: Combines EEG, EDA, and video signals to classify mental fatigue in construction workers.
examples.note: Added for its combination of EEG, EDA, and video signals, illustrating the application of multimodal data fusion in occupational safety and fatigue detection.

examples.description: Integrates EEG and ECG signals for drowsiness detection, demonstrating the effectiveness of a hybrid approach.

examples.description: Utilizes EEG, EOG, and ECG signals combined with subjective sleepiness measurements to improve the accuracy of drowsiness detection.

examples.description: Employs a multimodal system utilizing EEG, EOG, and ECG signals, emphasizing model robustness and explainability through SHAP analysis and partial dependency analysis.

examples.description: Combines EEG, EOG, and ECG for on-line mental fatigue monitoring, showing that EEG is the most effective modality, with ECG contributing positively when combined with EEG.
examples.note: Added for its investigation into the combination of EEG, EOG, and ECG for mental fatigue monitoring, highlighting the effectiveness of EEG and the positive contribution of ECG in a multimodal approach.

examples.description: Utilizes a combination of electroencephalography (EEG), electrodermal activity (EDA), and video signals for a multimodal approach to fatigue detection.

trend: Growing interest in multimodal data fusion to provide a more comprehensive and robust assessment of driver fatigue.
